Eighteen survivors of high voltage electrical injuries (HVEI) underwent neuropsychological evaluation in the acute, short-term or long-term epochs. While deficits in verbal learning and delayed recall of verbal information were present, anxiety in these patients often drove them to seek necessary interventions, highlighting their resilience and adaptive response, particularly beyond the acute period. The neurobehavioral effects of HVEI were very similar to those of a closely matched traumatic brain injury (TBI) control group in each epoch.
